oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thus far, our discussions have covered some of the aspects which must be taken into consideration in the design of clinical trials. These include the need for randomization of patients, types of controls, and the need for blinding. Everyone even peripherally associated with clinical trials appreciated being reminded of the characteristics and properties of randomized block design. All too often we, as statisticians, "reach for" a parametric procedure to evaluate the data when really we "know" a nonparametric test is what we should be using. This is like the clinician who "reaches for" the treatment before making the diagnosis. It goes without saying that each one of us needs to be reminded periodically that a correlation coefficient that is statistically different from zero is not tantamount to a cause and effect relationship.
